conversation.content: [frustrated] God, this pipe is just... it won't budge. I've been at this for, what, three hours now? [groan] Wait, there's something behind— [curious] Okay that's weird. There's like, um, there's actual brick back here. Not the cheap stuff they used in the seventies. [pause] This is... this is really old. [very quietly] Oh my God. There's writing on it. [excited] "Founded 1847 by—" I can't read the rest but— [gasp] there's more stuff back here! [very excited] Papers, they're wrapped in something, and is that... that's a photograph! [quickly] This changes everything, you know? They've been trying to tear this place down for years. [passionate] But if this is actually from the Underground Railroad era like I think it is— [laugh] oh man, the historical society is going to lose their minds! [anxious] I should, uh... I should probably stop touching everything. This could be really important. [relieved] But the building's safe now, right? They can't demolish a landmark. [happy] All this time I've been fixing leaky pipes in a piece of actual history. [chuckle] My boss is gonna be so confused when I call him. [hesitantly] "Hey, so the basement repair is on hold because, um, we might need archaeologists?" [laugh loudly] This is insane!

subject: Your maintenance work uncovering historical artifacts that change the building's landmark status
